author: danjmartin
title: danjmartin published UKIP to contest only two of the ten Leicestershire seats in the...
text:
UKIP to contest only two of the ten Leicestershire seats in the General Election By danjmartin | Posted: May 07, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Stuart Young is standing for UKIP in Leicester West in the General Election UKIP to contest only two of the ten Leicestershire seats in the General Election X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
UKIP will only have two General Election candidates in Leicestershire. 
The party is to contest the Leicester West and Harborough seats only, insisting it will focus it resources in areas where they have identified rival candidates as opponents of Brexit. 
In Leicester West, UKIP has selected Stuart Young to take on Labour's Liz Kendall , Tory candidate Jack Hickey and Lib Dem Ian Bradwell on June 8 . 
Mr Young was UKIP's Leicester West candidate in the 2015 General Election, finishing third behind Labour and the Tories with 17.2 per cent of the vote. 
General Election 2017: Click HERE for everything you need to know 
The 38-year-old bookkeeper lives in Leicester's West End. 
UKIP says it will shortly announce its Harborough candidate. 
The Tories have picked Neil O'Brien , an advisor to Theresa May and the former director of Policy Exchange and Open Europe to stand in a seat with a 19,000 Conservative majority. 
Chairman of UKIP's Leicestershire branch David Sprason said: "We are concentrating our efforts on seats that look likely to go to anti-Brexit candidates. 
"The Tories have picked a big Remainer for Harborough so we'll stand there. They also begged us not to stand in Leicester West because it would help them beat Liz Kendall but we are fighting that one." 
Mr Sprason said that decision was in part down to the anger among local UKIP members at comments made by Conservative county council leader Nick Rushton after UKIP lost their two seats at County Hall in Thursday's election. 
Mr Rushton described the UKIP two members, including Mr Sprason, as an anomaly and said he was glad they had lost. their seats. 
Mr Sprason added: "We fought long and hard about Loughborough and South Leicestershire where Nicky Morgan and Alberto Costa were anti-Brexit but they have changed their minds."
